titlePage.docAuthor: Archives Portal Europe Foundation's Working Group on Standards

div.head: Related Standards
div.p: Encoded Archival Guide (EAG), same as the related standards maintained by the Technical Subcommittee on Encoded Archival Standards (TS-EAS) at the Society of American Archivists (SAA), is an XML schema based on an established model developed by the International Council on Archives (ICA).

EAG is based on the International Standard for Describing Institutions with Archival Holdings (ISDIAH), while Encoded Archival Description (EAD) is based on the General International Standard Archival Description (ISAD(G)) and Encoded Archival Context for Corporate Bodies, Persons, and Families (EAC-CPF) on the International Standard Archival Authority Record for Corporate Bodies, Persons and Families (ISAAR-CPF). This revision to EAG was undertaken by the Archives Portal Europe Foundation's Working Group on Standards (WGoS) following the recent revision of EAC-CPF as well as requirements resulting from the use of EAG, and are not necessarily tied to ongoing developments of standards by the ICA, namely Records in Contexts (RiC), though the WGoS has been keeping close connections to the ICA Experts Group on Archival Description (EGAD) as a related standards body.

For this reason, this current release of EAG 3.0 will continue to be based on ISDIAH rather than the draft versions of RiC that were available during the revision process. We anticipate that future versions of EAG, along with future versions of the standards maintained by TS-EAS, will take the RiC Conceptual Model and/or the RiC Ontology into account once they are finalized and approved.

list.label: International Standard for Describing Institutions with Archival Holdings (ISDIAH)
list.item: ISDIAH is a descriptive standard for descriptions of entities (mainly corporate bodies, but potentially also persons and families) associated with the maintenance of archives. At the time of writing, ISDIAH is maintained by the International Council on Archives.
list.label: Encoded Archival Description (EAD)
list.item: EAD is an XML standard for encoding archival finding aids, maintained by the Technical Subcommittee for Encoded Archival Standards of the Society of American Archivists, in partnership with the Library of Congress.
list.label: Encoded Archival Context - Corporate Bodies, Persons, and Families (EAC-CPF)
list.item: EAC-CPF is an XML standard for encoding authority records for entities associated with the creation, use, and maintenance of archives, maintained by TS-EAS, in partnership with the Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin.
list.label: Encoding Standards
list.item: The international community of cultural heritage organizations is working on a broad set of diverse standards to meet the challenges of the digital age. Established standards concerning digitization and metadata are maintained by the Library of Congress.
list.label: Records in Contexts Conceptual Model
list.item: RiC-CM is a high-level conceptual model that focuses on intellectually identifying and describing records, the people that created and use(d) them, and the activities pursued by the people that the records both facilitate and document. RiC-CM is maintained by the International Council on Archives.
list.label: Records in Contexts Ontology
list.item: RiC-O is a formal representation of RiC-CM in the form of an OWL ontology. It provides a generic vocabulary and formal rules for creating RDF datasets that describe any kind of archival record resource in a consistent way. It can support publishing RDF datasets as Linked Data, querying them using SPARQL, and making inferences using the logic of the ontology.

div.head: Release and Revision Notes
div.p: This is the draft release of the Tag Library for EAG 3.0. This current version includes changes and updates in the schema undertaken by the WGoS reflecting comments received by the international community of professionals, aligning EAG with the other Encoded Archival Standards, EAD and EAC-CPF as maintained by the TS-EAS, and reviewing EAG from the perspective of aggregators such as Archives Portal Europe and the connected national aggregators across Europe.

The EAG Tag Library is a living document. As such, it will continue to be developed as users suggest areas in need of clarification or expansion. The WGoS still encourages implementers to provide any queries, comments, and suggestions regarding the Tag Library and its content. In addition, the contribution of examples is highly encouraged. Questions, comments or examples may be directed to the WGoS via email (standards[at]archivesportaleurope.net).

The underlying encoding of the Tag Library is based on TEI P5 and is designed to facilitate incorporating documentation into the schema to provide guidance in XML editors. While the initial release of the Tag Library is in English, the underlying encoding is designed to facilitate providing the Tag Library in additional languages at later dates.

The latest version of the EAG schema and Tag Library was adopted in 2012 during the APEx (Archives Portal Europe network of Excellence) project and saw minor updates during the years. This version was called EAG2012.

The process for a major revision started at the end of 2019 and was set out to follow the major revision of EAC-CPF, which had been started by the TS-EAS two years before that. The aim of this major revision has been to modernise the EAG schema in terms of:

list.item: - alignment with EAC-CPF, and to certain extent also with EAD, where useful,
- implementing features and solutions upon users’ request, with the specific user group of aggregators in mind

div.p: All elements and attributes in EAG2012 were evaluated in the process and so the present version, EAG 3.0, is the result of a major overhaul of the standard and a reconciliation with EAC-CPF 2.0 and EAD3. In more detail, the main changes compared to the previous version include:

list.label: Overall structure:
list.item: The overall structure of EAG 3.0 is now closer to the one of EAC-CPF 2.0, so that users of both standards will be able to draw comparisons and create relations more easily. This means that the root element eag now includes a mandatory control element and then allows for a choice between either a single repository or a grouping repositories element, which in itself can contain two or more repository elements. Each repository element includes the mandatory sub-element identity and description. Furthermore, repository and repositories alike include the optional sub-elements image and relations.
list.label: camelCase spelling:
list.item: EAG2012 included a mix of elements and attributes with and without camelCase spelling, i.e. the use of capital characters at the start of the second or third word when the element or attribute name results from a combination of several words. While elements and attributes that were introduced new in EAG2012 already followed the camelCase spelling, elements and attributes that had been inherited from EAG 0.2 did not. In EAG 3.0, all elements, attributes and attribute values use camelCase spelling, where applicable.
list.label: Adoption of attribute groups:
list.item: Following EAC-CPF 2.0, EAG 3.0 includes various attribute groups that are made available as optional extensions to a wide range of elements. All elements will have the attributes audience and id and all elements, but the root element eag include the attribute target to enable internal referencing from one element to another. All elements that can contain text, either within themselves or via their sub-elements, come with the attributes languageOfElement and scriptOfElement to support multilingual descriptions. Furthermore, the new attributes conventionDeclarationReference, maintenanceEventReference and sourceReference are available with all elements outside of control that can contain text. These elements can be used to refer back to the relevant sub-elements of control in order to specify the source of an element's content, the rules and conventions that have been applied when creating its content, and who provided its content when. Similarly, each localType attribute is now accompanied with an attribute localTypeDeclarationReference to provide more information about the value of localType.
list.label: External referencing:
list.item: EAG 3.0 allows for various ways of external referencing depending on the context. For elements, whose content is likely to come from a local, national, or international vocabulary or ontology, EAG 3.0 has enabled the attributes valueURI, vocabularySource and vocabularySourceURI to point to the origin of these terms. For more general referencing of external digital resources, the attributes href, linkTitle and linkRole (new) can now be used with more elements, especially in the description section, than in EAG2012. For referencing digital - or analog - resources in longer descriptive texts, e.g. in the element biogHist, the element reference is available and can be applied with or without the href attribute.
list.label: Alignment of the control element:
list.item: The elemen control in EAG 3.0 has been aligned with the same element as used in EAC-CPF 2.0, and as expected to be used in the next version of EAD. Among other things, the elements maintenanceStatus and publicationStatus have been turned into attributes of control, same as the elements agentType and eventType have been transformed into attributes of agent and maintenanceEvent respectively. Furthemore, the optional attributes countryEncoding, dateEncoding, languageEncoding, repositoryEncoding, and scriptEncoding as well as detailLevel have been added to control>. The restrictions regarding the content of the element recordId have been lifted and it can now contain any type of record identifier, but it has to have content, and within maintenanceAgency, one has to provide either an agencyCode or an agencyName and does not have to give both anymore. The structure of conventionDeclaration, localTypeDeclaration, and rightsDeclaration has been aligned and all three now also use reference instead of the separate, but similar citation along with the element shortCode (instead of abbreviation). Same as the other declaration elements, languageDeclaration is now a direct sub-element of control, while the plural version languageDeclarations has been removed completely. Last, the element representation has been introduced to allow for linking to other representation formats (e.g. an HTML page or a PDF document) based on the information in the EAG XML file.
list.label: Alignment with EAC-CPF in identity:
list.item: EAG 3.0 has adopted the element nameEntry and nameEntrySet from EAC-CPF to capture the various name forms of a repository. The former elements autform, parform, and nonpreform have been removed and the status of a name form as authorized or alternative can now be indicated via the status attribute, while a preferred form of name can be labeled as such with the preferredForm attribute. With this, any form of name can include useDates now. Furthermore, a new element otherRepositoryTypes has been added, similar to the element otherEntityTypes in EAC-CPF 2.0. It can be used to provide alternative, translated, or more specific terms for the repository type than the ones predefined in repositoryType.
list.label: Alignment with EAC-CPF in description:
list.item: Within the description section, various former elements have been replaced by equivalents inherited from EAC-CPF 2.0, where suitable, which has also allowed to streamline certain parts of the description. There now is one required places element, which can include one or more place elements holding location as well as contact information within its sub-elements address, contact, geographicCoordinates, placeName, and placeRole. The former elements geogarea, location, telephone, fax, email, webpage, and directions have been removed. Furthermore, repositorhist has been replaced by biogHist and instead of adminhierarchy the element structureOrGenealogy has been added. For the information about a repository's founding - and potential closure - the elements existDates and mandates have been borrowed from EAC-CPF, replacing repositorfound and repositorsup. Additionally, the elements functions and legalStatuses are now available in this context.
list.label: Changes and extenstions to EAG-specific elements:
list.item: The sub-elements of access have been renamed accessConditions and useConditions in order to be more precise, while the element accessibility, though still being considered important, has been made optional. All sub-elements of buildingInfo can now be repeated and the element repositoryRole does not prescribe any specific values anymore, but can be used with any term suitable. The sub-element actingMaintenanceForGroup of holdings has been removed completely. Instead, an option to include subject headings similar to EAD's controlled access terms has been introduced for holdings, so that it would still be possible to indicate that a repository has taken over the responsibilities of another by using the new sub-elements corpName and/or placeName. Furthermore, the sub-element extent of holdings can now be used with the attribute coverage to indicate whether a specific amount and unit of measurement applies to all holdings or only to a part. In this context, the available values for the unit attribute of the element num have been extended by values referring to the size of digital holdings. All services sub-elements have now been set up in the same way, including the question to simply indicated the general availability of a specific service as well as allowing for a textual description of the service and/or the inclusion of a link to the service itself or to an existing webpage describing the service in more detail; some selected services also include an option to contact details, e.g. for the library or the searchroom of a repository. Last, the elements multilingualServices, e.g. to indicate the availability of a website in different languages or the ability of the searchroom staff to support users in a variety of languages, and socialMedia to link to a repository's social media accounts have been introduced as new additions.
list.label: Alignment with EAC-CPF in relations:
list.item: The relations element and its sub-elements have been restructured significantly in EAC-CPF 2.0 and EAG 3.0 follows this new approach. The main change here comes from using only a general relation element with a required sub-element targetEntity to name the related entity, which in turn comes with a mandatory targetType attribute with the values "agent", "corporateBody", "family", "function", "person", or "resource", instead of using the specifically named element resourceRelation and eagRelation as in EAG2012.In addition, relation includes the optional and repeatable sub-elements relationType and targetRole for a more precise description of the relationship between the repository described and the related entity.

div.head: Tag Library Conventions
div.p: The EAG Elements section of the Tag Library contains descriptions of 121 elements, arranged alphabetically by element name.

list.label: Tag Name:
list.item: Short, mnemonic form of the element name that is used in the machine-readable encoded document. The tag name is the first word at the top of the page. Tag names appear between angle brackets, e.g., nameEntry, except in the listings under "May occur within" and "May contain," and are always in camel case (camelCase).
list.label: Element Name:
list.item: Expanded version of the tag name that more fully describes the element's meaning. The full name of the element is usually a word or phrase that identifies the element's purpose. In the Tag Library, the element name follows the tag name on the page defining that element and appears with initial capital letters, e.g., for nameEntry it says "Name Entry".
list.label: Summary:
list.item: A brief statement that provides a concise definition of the element, suitable for quick reference.
list.label: May Contain:
list.item:
Identifies what child nodes (text or elements) may occur within the element being defined. Child elements are listed in alphabetical order by tag name. Elements may be empty (e.g., an element which allows no child text or element nodes), or they may contain text (listed as [text]), other elements, or a mixture of text and other elements.
Text content cannot include characters that would be interpreted by a parser as action codes. For example, a left angle bracket has to be represented as the character entity reference < so that it is not misinterpreted as the start of an element name.
The technical availability of child elements is listed in brackets beside each element, e.g. place (0..1). The first character represents the minimum occurrences of the child element and the final character represents the maximum occurrences of the child element, with "n" representing unlimited occurrences.
list.label: May Occur Within:
list.item: Identifies all of the parent elements within which the described element may appear, listed in alphabetical order by tag name. This conveys information about where and how often an element is available throughout the schema. The definitions for parent elements may provide additional information about an element's usage.
list.label: Attributes:
list.item: Identifies all attributes that can be associated with an element. Attributes are represented in camelCase letters in XML coding. The Tag Library uses the convention of preceding an attribute name with an @ symbol (e.g., localType), following XPath syntax. See the EAG Attributes section of the Tag Library for definitions and additional information.
list.label: Description and Usage:
list.item:
This section begins with one or more paragraphs that provide a more thorough description of the element than that found in the Summary, which may be followed by guidance on use. The terms "parent" and "child" (or "sub-element") are used to indicate hierarchical relationships between elements. Standard terminology is also used to suggest the kind of element being discussed. "Wrapper element" indicates an element that cannot contain text directly; a second, nested element must be opened first. When the schema enforces a specific sequence of child elements, that sequence is indicated.
If useful, context-specific guidance for the usage of an element's attributes is given in an "Attribute usage" section. A "See also" section may be provided to indicate additional elements that are similar, easily confused, or otherwise related to the element being described.
list.label: Availability:
list.item: Indicates, within the context of its parent(s), whether the element is required or optional, and whether or not it is repeatable.
list.label: Examples:
list.item: Element and attribute descriptions include one or more tagged example(s) to indicate how attributes and elements can be used together. Many of the examples are taken from real institution descriptions; others have been specially constructed for the Tag Library. The examples illustrate any required sequences of elements, as in the case of children within control, or required sub-elements such as part in nameEntry. In other cases, the examples simply show what is possible. Some examples have ellipses, either between or within elements, indicating that other elements or text have been omitted. Some elements have multiple examples: one may show very dense markup with numerous attributes while another may illustrate a minimalist approach to the markup. Either approach is valid in EAG, and it is up to the instance creator to determine the optimal level of markup based on their specific purposes, functional requirements, resources, or consortial guidelines.

div.p: An optional element within biogHist that contains a brief summary of the information contained within the biogHist as a whole.

The abstract is a brief synopsis of the identity's biography or history that is often based on the longer descriptions found in biogHist. Its purpose is to help readers quickly identify the identity described in the EAC-CPF instance. The content within this element may also be harvested by other systems to provide explanatory context for the nameEntry data when it appears in a set of search results.
abstract may include one or more reference elements to point to external resources that provide additional descriptive data.
Conditions, requirements and procedures for access and use of the archival holdings.

list.label: question
list.item: Required (values limited to: no, yes, yes (conditions apply))

div.p: Element to capture nformation on conditions and requirements for access and use like access policies, terms of use, fees etc. A general statement on whether or not an institution with archival holdings is accessible is mandatory and can be added using the attribute question with values "yes" or "no" or "yes (conditions apply"). Additionally, access supports a link to existing websites with more details.
Use the subelements accessConditions and useConditions to include more specific URLs e.g. to documents containing terms of use, any registration forms that need to be filled beforehand, etc.

access.question: yes
access.accessConditions: To prepare for your personal use of the reference service, or should you require written information, you may send an informal written reference [...].
access.useConditions: General information on access and use

div.p: Information on conditions of access relating to the archival holdings, could also include information like "by appointment with the archivist only".
Details about services for users with disabilities.

Use this element to provide information about any details regarding enhanced accessibility for users with disabilities such as building features, specialised equipment or tools, parking or lifts, etc.

eag:description.eag:accessibility: There are dedicated parking areas available for persons with disabilities. Access to the building is at ground level and there are lifts to the upper floors of the reading room.

div.p: An optional child element of place that binds together one or more addressLine elements to encode a postal or other address.
address is an optional wrapper element within place used to encode a physical or analog address.
Ideally address should be bundled with a placeName element within place to provide both the name and address of a location.
address must include one or more addressLine element(s) that provide full or sufficient information identifying a postal or other physical address related to the entity being described.
One of address, placeName, placeRole, geographicCoordinates, or contact is required within place.

list.item: Use contact to encode digital addresses and contact information.

div.p: A required child element of address used for recording one line of a postal or other address.

list.label: addressLineType
list.item: Optional (values limited to: county, country, district, municipality, postBox, postalCode, region, street)
list.label: audience
conventionDeclarationReference
id
languageOfElement
localType
localTypeDeclarationReference
maintenanceEventReference
scriptOfElement
sourceReference
target

div.p: addressLine is used to encode parts or lines of a physical address within a parent address element.
addressLine may be repeated as many times as necessary to enter all parts of an address.

list.item: Use one of the set values in the optional addressLineType attribute to encode the part of the address that the addressLine refers to, for example "street".

div.p: Statement whether it is possible to order records in advance.

A general statement whether it is possible to order records in advance can be given using the attribute question with the values "yes" or "no" or "yes (conditions apply)". You can either add more information into the element directly or you can use the attribute href to link to an online form or similar.

eag:searchroom.eag:advancedOrders: El usuario pueden realizar tanto petición anticipada de la documentación como reserva de la misma

div.p: A child element of maintenanceAgency that provides a code for the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance.

Use agencyCode to record a code indicating the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance. Use of agencyCode is recommended, as the combination of agencyCode and the required recordId provide a globally unique identifier for the instance.
maintenanceAgency must include one or both of agencyCode and agencyName.

It is recommended that the code follow the format of the International Standard Identifier for Libraries and Related Organizations (ISIL: ISO 15511): a prefix, a dash, and an identifier. The code is alphanumeric (characters A-Z, 0-9, solidus, hyphen-minus, and colon) with a maximum of 16 characters. If appropriate to local or national convention, insert a valid ISIL for an institution, whether provided by a national authority (usually the national library) or a service (such as OCLC). If this is not the case then local institution codes may be given with the ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code as the prefix to ensure international uniqueness in agencyCode.

list.item: Use status with the value "authorized" or "alternative" to declare whether the agencyCode is using an authorized value, e.g. a registered ISIL code, or an alternative one.
Use agencyName to record the name of the agency.
Use otherAgencyCode to record any alternative codes representing the agency.
Use recordId in combination with agencyCode to provide a globally unique identifier for the EAC-CPF instance.

div.p: A child element of maintenanceAgency that provides the name of the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance.

Use agencyName to record the name of the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance. Examples include the repository name or the name of an aggregation service.
maintenanceAgency must include one or both of agencyName and agencyCode.
It is recommended to use the form of the agency name that is authorized by an appropriate national or international agency or service.

agencyName may be repeated in order to provide the name of the institution or service responsible for the EAC-CPF instance in multiple languages. If agencyName is repeated it is recommended to indicate the language of each name using languageOfElement.

list.item: Use agencyCode to record a code representing the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance.

div.p: A required child element of maintenanceEvent that provides the name of a person, institution, or system responsible for a specific event in the EAC-CPF instance's maintenance history, such as its creation, modification, or deletion.

list.label: agentType
list.item: Required (values limited to: human, machine, unknown)
list.label: audience
id
languageOfElement
scriptOfElement
target
valueURI
vocabularySource
vocabularySourceURI

div.p: Use agent to indicate the person, institution, or system responsible for a maintenance event. Examples include the name of the author or encoder, the database responsible for creating the EAC-CPF instance, and the style sheet used to update an instance to a new version of EAC-CPF.
Each maintenanceEvent element must have a child agent element.

list.item: Use the required agentType attribute to specify whether the agent is "human", "machine", or "unknown".

div.p: A concise essay and/or chronology that provides biographical or historical information about the EAC-CPF entity.
biogHist includes significant details about the life of an individual or family, or the administrative history of a corporate body.

The biogHist element may contain text in a series of paragraphs (p), and/or a chronology list (chronList) that matches dates and date ranges with associated events and/or places. The abstract element is intended to provide a very brief synopsis of the full biogHist content that could be extracted for inclusion in a remote source, such as a MARC record.

The optional list element is used to accommodate greater complexity in expressing or representing the biography or history of the CPF entity. A simpler discursive expression of the information may be encoded as one or more p elements. The optional head element can be used to add a title or caption to the text.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One or more of chronList, list, or p

div.p: General characteristics and/or history of the repository building.

eag:buildingInfo.eag:building: El archivo está instalado en un edificio reedificado en 1972 sobre las antiguas dependencias del Tribunal de la Chancillería, respetando el estilo constructivo del siglo XVII. Con un total de 6.665 m2 de superficie construída, se divide en un edificio principal en el que se ubican los distintos servicios del archivo, y un edificio de siete plantas destinado a depósito documental. Entre los años 2008 y 2011 se realizaron obras de reestructuración y accesibilidad de instalaciones que han tenido como objetivo último la redistribución de los espacios para conseguir un mejor aprovechamiento de la superficie de las plantas, un mejor servicio al usuario en general y a las personas discapacitadas en particular, y una mejora de las condiciones de los trabajadores.

div.p: Information about the repository building and its features
Use the subelements of buildingInfo to provide general characteristics of the building (building), area (repositoryArea) and capacity of storage (lengthOfShelvesd) of the repository.

eag:buildingInfo.eag:building: El archivo está instalado en un edificio reedificado en 1972 sobre las antiguas dependencias del Tribunal de la Chancillería, respetando el estilo constructivo del siglo XVII. Con un total de 6.665 m2 de superficie construída, se divide en un edificio principal en el que se ubican los distintos servicios del archivo, y un edificio de siete plantas destinado a depósito documental. Entre los años 2008 y 2011 se realizaron obras de reestructuración y accesibilidad de instalaciones que han tenido como objetivo último la redistribución de los espacios para conseguir un mejor aprovechamiento de la superficie de las plantas, un mejor servicio al usuario en general y a las personas discapacitadas en particular, y una mejora de las condiciones de los trabajadores.

div.p: A required element within chronList that pairs a date with one or more events and zero or more places within a chronology list.
chronItemSet (0..n), date or dateRange or dateSet (1..1), event (1..1), place (0..1), reference (0..n)

A required element within a chronology list, chronItem must contain date, dateRange, or dateSet followed by an event or chronItemSet. Use dateRange to record an inclusive pair of dates or dateSet to record multiple dates or date ranges.
An optional place element may be used alongside event to detail a place that is relevant to the chronology item.
chronItemSet can be used to record multiple events or places within a single chronItem.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One of date, dateRange, or dateSet
Use localType, if local use requires specification of the type of chronological item.

div.p: An element for binding together one or more event elements and zero or more place elements within chronItem.

Use chronItemSet within chronItem when it is necessary to associate multiple event elements and multiple place elements. Possible combinations include multiple events, a single event associated with multiple locations, multiple events associated with a single location, or multiple events associated with multiple locations. chronItemSet may be repeated within chronItem when necessary to associate multiple instances of such combinations with the date or dates recorded within chronItem.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One or more of place or reference

div.p: An optional child element of biogHist used to document a structured chronological list of events, dates, and (optionally) places.

chronList comprises a sequentially structured list of significant events in the life of the person or during the existence of the family or corporate body described in the EAC-CPF instance. Such events are associated with the date of occurrence and optionally with the name of a place.
Each chronList contains one or more chronItem elements, each associating a date, dateRange, or dateSet with an event and an optional place.
An optional child element of source that identifies precisely where supporting evidence was found within the source.

The citedRange element can be used to refer to a specific location within a source where supporting evidence can be found. It may refer to a specific location such as a single page, or a broader location such as a range of pages.

list.item: Use the optional unit attribute to specify the format that the citedRange refers to, for example page number or volume number.

div.p: Dates and times of closure of the repository.

eag:timetable.eag:closing: Fiestas locales (San Ildefonso y Corpus Christi, variables anualmente), fiestas nacionales, fiestas de la comunidad autónoma (31 de mayo), 24 de diciembre y 31 de diciembre.

div.p: Number of work places fitted with computer devices available in the reading room.
Number of work places in the reading room that have been fitted with computers or provide options to connect one's own device.
An optional child element of place that binds together one or more contactLine elements to encode contact details or digital addresses.
contact is an optional wrapper element within place used to encode digital addresses and contact information.
contact must include one or more contactLine element(s) that provide relevant contact details for the entity being described.
One of contact, placeName, placeRole, geographicCoordinates, or address is required within place.

list.item: Use address to encode a physical or analog address.

div.p: A required child element of contact used for recording one line of contact details or digital addresses.

list.label: audience
contactLineType
list.item: Optional (values limited to: directions, email, fax, homepage, mobileNumber, phoneNumber)
list.label: conventionDeclarationReference
href
id
languageOfElement
linkRole
linkTitle
localType
localTypeDeclarationReference
maintenanceEventReference
scriptOfElement
sourceReference
target

div.p: contactLine is used to encode separate details or lines of contact details or digital addresses within a parent contact element.
contactLine may be repeated as many times as necessary to enter all relevant contact details.

list.item: Use one of the set values in the optional contactLineType attribute to encode the type of contact detail that the contactLine refers to, for example "phoneNumber".

div.p: A required child element of eac that contains information about the creation, maintenance, status and the rules and authorities used in the composition of the EAC-CPF instance.

conventionDeclaration (0..n), languageDeclaration (0..n), localControl (0..n), localTypeDeclaration (0..n), maintenanceAgency (1..1), maintenanceHistory (1..1), otherRecordId (0..n), recordId (1..1), rightsDeclaration (0..n), representation (0..n), sources (0..1)

div.p: This required wrapper element within eac contains the information necessary to manage the instance. This includes information about its creation, maintenance and status as well as the languages, rules and authorities used in the composition of the description.

It must contain a unique identifier for the instance within the recordId element. Other associated identifiers may be given in otherRecordId. There must be a description of the agency responsible for its creation and maintenance in maintenanceAgency as well as statements about its current drafting status in maintenanceStatus and the creation, maintenance, and disposition of the instance in maintenanceHistory.

There are optional elements available to declare languages, rules, conventions and sources used in the EAC-CPF instance. Other control elements considered necessary but not otherwise included may be given in the localControl element. Similarly, local types for certain elements used throughout the EAC-CPF instance are recommended to be defined in the localTypeDeclaration element
The available child elements (both required and optional), in their prescribed order, are:

list.item: recordId - Required. Contains the unique identifier for the EAC-CPF instance.
maintenanceAgency - Required. Contains the name and coded information about the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance.
maintenanceHistory - Required. Contains information about the date, type and events within the life cycle of an EAC-CPF instance.
sources - Optional. Contains information about the sources consulted in creating the description of the entity or entities in the EAC-CPF instance.

The following elements may appear in any order after the above elements:
conventionDeclaration - Optional. Contains information on the rules or conventions used to construct the EAC-CPF instance.
languageDeclaration - Optional. Contains coded and natural language information about the language or languages of the EAC-CPF instance.
localControl - Optional. Contains any administrative metadata necessary due to local practice that are not represented by the other elements in control.
localTypeDeclaration - Optional. Contains information about local conventions used in the localType attribute.
otherRecordId - Optional. An element that allows the recording of additional identifiers that may be associated with the EAC-CPF instance.
representation - Optional. Used for recording a link to a transformed and deliverable version of the EAC-CPF instance.
rightsDeclaration - Optional. Contains information about the usage rights of the EAC-CPF instance.
Use the required maintenanceStatus attribute to document the current version status of the EAC-CPF instance.
Use the optional publicationStatus attribute to record the editorial status of the EAC-CPF instance.

div.p: An optional child element of control, used to declare the rules or conventions, including authorized controlled vocabularies and thesauri, applied in creating the EAC-CPF instance.

conventionDeclaration is used for declaring references to any rules and conventions, including authorized controlled vocabularies or thesauri, applied in the construction of the description. The element binds together the required reference element with optional shortCode and descriptiveNote elements that identify rules or conventions applied in compiling the EAC-CPF instance.
Each additional rule or set of rules, controlled vocabulary, or standard should be contained in a separate conventionDeclaration.
shortCode may be used to identify the standard or controlled vocabulary in a coded structure. Any notes relating to how these rules or conventions have been used may be given within descriptiveNote.
It may not be necessary to include conventionDeclaration in such cases where the above scenarios are addressed in local or consortial documentation.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
An element for identifying the name of an organization or group of people.

The single date of an event in the history of the person, family, or corporate body being described, or in their relationship to, e.g., a name entry, a place, an occupation, another CPF entity, a resource, or a function.
chronItem, dateSet, existDates, function, legalStatus, localControl, localDescription, mandate, occupation, otherEntityType, place, relation, useDates

An element for expressing the single date of an event in the history of the person, corporate body or family being described, or in their relationship to, e.g., a name entry, a place, an occupation, another CPF entity, a resource, or a function.

The content of the element is intended to be a human-readable natural language date with a machine-readable date provided as the value of the standardDate attribute, formulated according to ISO 8601. Uncertain or approximate dates can be encoded in standardDate using Extended Date/Time Format (EDTF).
If the event or relationship has inclusive dates use the dateRange element, while more complex dates (combining singles dates and date ranges) can be expressed in dateSet.

Dates of existence for the entity being described are encoded with the existDates element, while the dates of use of a particular name of an entity are encoded in useDates. The date and time of a maintenance event in the history of the EAC-CPF instance are given in the eventDateTime element.

list.item: Use certainty to indicate the degree of precision in the dating, for example, "uncertain" or "approximate".
Use localType to supply a more specific characterization of the date.
Use notAfter and notBefore to capture the latest and earliest possible dates in machine-processable form in cases when the date is uncertain.
Use standardDate to provide a machine-processable form of the date.
Use status with the value "unknown" to indicate where a date is unknown.

div.p: Within function, legalStatus, localDescription, mandate, occupation, otherEntityType, place, relation: one of date, dateRange, or dateSet optional, not repeatable
Within chronItem, existDates and useDates: one of date, dateRange, or dateSet required, not repeatable
Within dateSet: at least two of date and/or dateRange required, repeatable
Within localControl: one of date or dateRange optional, not repeatable

A wrapper element for binding together fromDate and toDate in order to represent a range of dates. Either fromDate or toDate must be present within a dateRange, but it is recommended to use both child elements whenever possible.
chronItem, dateSet, existDates, function, legalStatus, localControl, localDescription, mandate, occupation, otherEntityType, place, relation, useDates
An element that expresses inclusive dates of an event in the history of, or a relationship with, the person, family, or corporate body being described in the EAC-CPF instance.

dateRange contains fromDate and/or toDate, and therefore may express a range of dates as a starting point with no end point, a start and end point, or an end point with no starting point. Either fromDate or toDate must be present within a dateRange, but it is recommended to use both child elements whenever possible.

The content of the children of dateRange is intended to be a human-readable, natural language expression of the dates. If, however, indexing or other machine processing of dates is desired, standardDate should be used on the children of dateRange to record the date in machine-processable form as well.

Dates of existence for the identity being described are encoded with the existDates element, while the dates of use of a particular name of an identity are encoded in useDates. The date and time of a maintenance event in the history of the EAC-CPF instance are given in the eventDateTime element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: Use localType to supply a more specific characterization of the date range.

div.p: Within function, legalStatus, localDescription, mandate, occupation, otherEntityType, place, relation: one of date, dateRange, or dateSet optional, not repeatable
Within chronItem, existDates and useDates: one of date, dateRange, or dateSet required, not repeatable
Within dateSet: at least two of date and/or dateRange required, repeatable
Within localControl: one of date or dateRange optional, not repeatable
A wrapper element for encoding complex dates that cannot be adequately represented in one date or dateRange.
chronItem, existDates, function, holdings, legalStatus, mandate, otherRepositoryType, place, relation, useDates

dateSet binds together single dates and date ranges, multiple single dates, or multiple date ranges. dateSet is used in situations where complex date information needs to be conveyed and requires at least two child elements. These can be any combination of date and dateRange.
Within function, legalStatus, mandate, otherRepositoryType, place, relation, holdings: one of date, dateRange, or dateSet optional, not repeatable
Within chronItem, existDates, useDates: one of date, dateRange, or dateSet required, not repeatable
An optional child element of cpfDescription, description is a wrapper element for all of the content elements comprising descriptive information about the CPF entity.

biogHist (0..n), existDates (0..n), functions (0..1), generalContext (0..n), languagesUsed (0..1), legalStatuses (0..1), localDescriptions (0..1), mandates (0..1), occupations (0..1), places (0..1), structureOrGenealogy (0..n)

The child elements that constitute description together permit descriptive information to be encoded in either structured or unstructured fashions, or in a combined approach. description accommodates the encoding of all the data elements that comprise the Description Area of ISAAR (CPF) including historical, biographical, and genealogical information; legal status and mandates; functions, occupations, and activities, and the dates and places that further constrain those elements.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: Any of biogHist, existDates, generalContext, and structureOrGenealogy

div.p: An element used to provide general descriptive information related to its parent element.

conventionDeclaration, existDates, function, functions, identity, languageDeclaration, languageUsed, languagesUsed, legalStatus, legalStatuses, localDescription, localDescriptions, localTypeDeclaration, maintenanceAgency, mandate, mandates, occupation, occupations, otherEntityType, otherEntityTypes, place, places, relation, relations, rightsDeclaration, setComponent, source, sources
descriptiveNote provides additional descriptive information about the element in which it is contained. descriptiveNote must contain one or more p elements.
Mandatory root element that indicates a description of an institution with archival holdings formatted in XML and encoded according to the EAG standard.
A child element of chronItem or chronItemSet that is used to encode an event associated with a date, and optionally a place, within a structured chronology.

event contains discursive text identifying the event described by the chronItem or chronItemSet. chronItem must include one of either event or chronItemSet. chronItemSet must include one or more event elements.
Every event must have date(s) (date, dateRange, or dateSet) associated with it. It may also have optional place element associated with it.
Within chronItem: One of chronItemSet or event required, not repeatable.
A required child element of maintenanceEvent that records the date and time of a specific maintenance action for an EAC-CPF instance.

A required child element of maintenanceEvent, eventDateTime is for recording the date and time that a maintenance event occurred. Examples of maintenance events include the creation, update, revision, or other modification to an EAC-CPF instance.

The date and time may be captured in natural language in the element. It is highly recommended to provide at least a human-readable date in eventDateTime directly or a machine-processable date in standardDateTime, in case it is not possible to provide both.

list.item: Use standardDateTime to provide a machine-processable expression of the date or date and time, formulated according to the ISO 8601 standard.

div.p: An optional child element of maintenanceEvent that provides the description of a maintenance event in the life of the EAC-CPF instance.

A child element of maintenanceEvent used for describing the maintenance event. The element allows a full description of the maintenance event to be given alongside information about the maintenance agent, and the type, time and date of the maintenance event.
Statement on exhibitions run by the institution with archival holdings.
Statement on current, previous or upcoming exhibitions, onsite or online, organised and run by the institution with archival holdings.
Provide additional information in the element and/or use the attribute href to include a link to either a website giving more details or, in case of online exhibitions, to the exhibition page itself.

An optional element within description used for encoding the dates of existence of the CPF entity being described, such as dates of establishment and dissolution for corporate bodies and dates of birth and death or floruit for persons.
date or dateRange or dateSet (1..1), descriptiveNote (0..1)
The dates of existence of the CPF entity being described, such as dates of establishment and dissolution for corporate bodies and dates of birth and death or floruit for persons.

existDates must contain one of date, dateRange, or dateSet. These child elements may contain actual or approximate dates. A descriptiveNote may be included if a fuller explanation of the dates of existence is needed.

Use the date element to record the date of a single event, such as a date of birth or date of incorporation. Use dateRange to encode a pair of inclusive dates. Use dateSet to encode more complex date expressions that intermix date and dateRange elements.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One of date, dateRange, or dateSet
Do not confuse with useDates, which is a child element of nameEntry or nameEntrySet and represents the dates of use for a particular name or set of names.

div.p: An element for identifying the name of a group of people with blood relations, or persons who form a household.
A child element of dateRange that records the starting point in a range of dates.

Use fromDate to record the beginning date in a range of dates. fromDate may contain actual, approximate or unknown dates. The content of the element is intended to be a human-readable, natural language expression of the date. If, however, indexing or other machine processing of dates is desired, the standardDate should be used to record the date in machine-processable form as well. If the fromDate is not known, it may be omitted from dateRange, or the status attribute used.

list.item: Use certainty to indicate the degree of precision in the dating, for example, "uncertain" or "approximate".
Use localType to supply a more specific characterization of the start date.
Use notAfter and notBefore to capture the latest and earliest possible dates in machine-processable form in cases when the date is uncertain.
Use standardDate to provide a machine-processable form of the date.
Use status with the value "unknown" to indicate where the start of a date range is unknown.
Use toDate to record the ending point of a date range.

div.p: A required child element of functions that provides information about a function, activity, role, or purpose performed by the CPF entity being described.
date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1), placeName (0..n), term (1..n)

A function element is a wrapper element used to encode an index term, using the required child element term. Terms are used to identify the functions, processes, activities, tasks, or transactions performed by the CPF entity. They may be drawn from controlled vocabularies or may be natural language terms.

function must include at least one term element. term can be repeated within function to include translations of the same function. Use the languageOfElement attribute to identify the language used in each term.

Associated date(s) (date, dateRange, or dateSet) and place(s) (placeName) may be included to further constrain the term's meaning. A descriptiveNote may be included if a fuller textual explanation is needed.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One of date, dateRange, or dateSet
Use relation with targetEntity having the targetType "function" when describing the relationship between the function and the CPF entity being described in more detail.

div.p: An optional child element of description used for grouping together one or more function elements.
Use the optional functions element to group together one or more occurrences of function. functions must include at least one function element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
An element for encoding a genre or form of material.
An optional child element of place that encodes a set of geographic coordinates.
Use geographicCoordinates to express a set of geographic coordinates such as latitude, longitude, and altitude representing a point, line, or area on the surface of the earth.
It is recommended that the values included in geographicCoordinates are based on a commonly used system for expressing geographic coordinates.
One of geographicCoordinates, placeName, placeRole, address, or contact is required within place.

list.item: Use the required coordinateSystem attribute to provide a commonly used code for the system used to express the coordinates. Examples include WGS84, OSGB36, ED50.

div.p: An element that encodes a title or caption for a section of text.
head is used for supplying title-like statements to a section of text or a list. When head is used, it must be the first child element, followed by one or more other elements.
Archival and other holdings of the institution.
corpName (0..n), date or dateRange or dateSet (0...1), descriptiveNote (0..1), extent (0..n), famName (0..n), genreForm (0..n), name (0..n), persName (0..n), placeName (0..n), subject (0..n)
The element holdings allows giving a concise overview of one's holdings, including date and extent information as well as narrative text using descriptiveNote.

eag:descriptiveNote.eag:p: The Federal Archives have the legal responsibility of permanently preserving the federal archival documents and making them available for use. This includes documents (files, papers, cartographic records, pictures, posters, films, sound recordings and machine-readable data) arising from the central institutions of the Holy Roman Empire (1495-1806), the German Confederation (1815-1866), the German Reich (1867/71-1945), the occupation zones (1945-1949), the German Democratic Republic (1949-1990) and the Federal Republic of Germany (since 1949). The Federal Archives decide whether these documents are assigned a lasting value for research into, or understanding of, German history, the ensuring of the legitimate interests of citizens or the provision of information for legislation, administration and jurisdiction.

The Foundation Archives of Parties and Mass Organisations of the GDR in the Federal Archives keeps the archives of the central leadership organs of the parties, unions and mass organisations of the GDR. It also looks after the Federal Archives Library, the core of which is formed by the library of the former Institute for Marxism-Leninism and other GDR service and organisation libraries.

The Federal Archives also collect personal papers of important personages, documents of parties, associations and societies of cross-regional importance, as well as published sources. Non-state records are acquired for the Federal Archives through an active acquisition and transfer policy. Defined collection profiles determine which personal papers and collections or papers of associations and parties, can meaningfully supplement the state archives.

div.p: A required child element of repository used to encode the name or names related to the repository being described within the EAG instance and other information that helps to identify the institution.
descriptiveNote (0..1), nameEntry or nameEntrySet (1..n), otherRepositoryId (0..n), otherRepositoryTypes (0..1), repositoryId (0..1), repositoryType (0..n)
identity is a wrapper element used to group the elements necessary to encode the name or names related to the repository being described within the repository element.

One or more nameEntry elements and/or one or more nameEntrySet elements must be included. All names by which the repository being described within one repository element is known are provided within identity. Each of the names, whether authorized or alternatives, should be recorded in a separate nameEntry element.

identity may accommodate two or more parallel names in different languages or scripts. In countries where there is more than one official language, such as Canada or Switzerland, names of repositories are frequently provided in more than one language. Within identity, a nameEntrySet element should be used to group two or more nameEntry elements that represent parallel forms of the name of the repository being described.

An optional repositoryId is available for the main authorized identifier associated with the repository. Any number of additional and alternative identifiers may be given in the optional and repeatable element otherRepositoryId.

An optional repositoryType provides a predefined list to select the type(s) of repository from. Additionally, the optional otherRepositoriyTypes element can be used to encode other repository types not included in this list as well as translations or specifications of those repository types.
Within identity, a descriptiveNote element may be used to record other information in a textual form that assists in the identification of the repository.
In case multiple repositories are described within the same EAG instance, a separate identity element is contained in each of the repository elements of the EAG instance.
The prescribed order of all child elements is:
Logo or other imagery representation of the institution.
Information about the vailability of Internet access at the repository.
Information about the availability of Internet access at the repository, including the option to provide details about the terms for Internet access or possibly existing fees.

eag:services.eag:internetAccess: Internet can be accessed for free via the 35 computer places in the reading room. The repository, however, does not have any facilities for wireless Internet access.

div.p: A child element of list that encodes the individual items in a list.
The item element is used for general lists within descriptive elements.

list.item: Do not confuse with chronItem, which encodes entries within a structured chronology, chronList.

div.p: An optional child element of control that indicates the language and script in which an EAC-CPF instance is written.

An optional child element of control that declares the languages and scripts in which an EAC-CPF instance is written in the languageCode and scriptCode attributes. Any comments about the languages and scripts in which the EAC-CPF instance is written may be included in the optional descriptiveNote element.

list.item: Use the required languageCode to provide a code for the language used in the EAC-CPF instance.
Use languageOfElement to provide a code for the language in which the languageDeclaration element is given.
Use scriptCode to provide a code for the writing system used in the EAC-CPF instance.
Use scriptOfElement to provide a code for the writing system in which the languageDeclaration element is given.

div.p: A required child element of legalStatuses used to encode information about the legal status of a corporate body.
date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1), placeName (0..n), term (1..n)

The legal status of a corporate body is typically defined and granted by authorities or through authorized agencies. Enter terms in accordance with provisions of the controlling legislation. Terms may be drawn from controlled vocabularies or may be natural language terms.

legalStatus must include at least one term element, where the legal status of the corporate body is encoded. term can be repeated within legalStatus to include translations of the same term. Use the languageOfElement attribute to identify the language used in each term.

Associated date(s) (date, dateRange, or dateSet) and place(s) (placeName) may be included to further constrain the term's meaning. A descriptiveNote element may be included if a fuller textual explanation is needed.
Multiple legalStatus elements may be grouped within a legalStatuses element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One of date, dateRange, or dateSet

div.p: An optional child element of description used to bundle together one or more legalStatus element.
legalStatuses groups together one or more occurrences of legalStatus. legalStatuses must include at least one legalStatus element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Information about the length of shelves at the repository building.
Information about the length of shelves at the repository building including the respective unit of measurement in the accompanying attribute unit.
Information about the availability of a library for consultation at the premises of the repository.
A wrapper element used to encode a simple list consisting of one or more item elements, or a complex list with one or more child list elements.
The list element is used for general lists that can be embedded with a large number of descriptive elements.

To encode a simple list, include one or more item elements within list. To encode more complex lists, such as hierarchies, additional list elements can be included within list. head can be used to encode a title or caption within a list.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One or both of list and item
Use listType to identify and format the list as a particular type. The choices are: "ordered," and "unordered."
Do not confuse with chronList, which encodes a structured chronology.

div.p: An optional child element of control, used to specify any control information necessary to accommodate local practice.
An element used to record and define any control information necessary to accommodate local practice, in addition to the elements otherwise made available within control.
The value of the entry must be given in a child term element and an associated date or range of dates can be given as either date or dateRange.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: Use localType if local practice requires recording the type of entry.

div.p: An optional child element of control used to declare any local conventions or controlled vocabularies used in localType in the EAC-CPF instance.
localTypeDeclaration specifies the local conventions and controlled vocabularies used in localType attributes in the EAC-CPF instance.

The child reference must be used to cite the resource that lists the local rules or controlled terms. Any notes relating to how these rules or conventions have been used may be given in descriptiveNote. The child shortCode may be used to identify any abbreviation or code representing the local convention or controlled vocabulary.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
A required child element of control that identifies the institution or service responsible for the EAC-CPF instance.
maintenanceAgency encodes information about the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance.

maintenanceAgency must include one or both of agencyCode or agencyName to provide the name of the institution or service. It may also include the optional child element otherAgencyCode to provide any additional identifiers. Any general information about the institution in relation to the EAC-CPF instance may be given in descriptiveNote.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: Use countryCode to indicate a unique code for the country of the maintenance agency.

div.p: A required child element of maintenanceHistory used to record information about maintenance activities in the history of the EAC-CPF instance.

list.label: audience
id
languageOfElement
maintenanceEventType
list.item: Required (values limited to: cancelled, created, deleted, derived, revised, unknown, updated)
list.label: scriptOfElement
target

div.p: A required child element of maintenanceHistory, maintenanceEvent is used to record an activity in the creation and ongoing maintenance of an EAC-CPF instance, including revisions, updates, and deletions. There will always be at least one maintenance event for each instance, which will typically be its creation.
maintenanceEvent must include agent and eventDateTime child elements to record the agent that carried out the maintenance event, and the date and time the maintenance event occurred.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: Use the required maintenanceEventType to document the type of maintenance activity that the maintenanceEvent is recording, using one of the values from the available controlled list.

div.p: A required child element of control that captures the history of the creation and maintenance of the EAC-CPF instance.
A required child element of control, maintenanceHistory is for recording the history of the creation, revisions, updates, and other modifications to the EAC-CPF instance.

There must be at least one child maintenanceEvent in maintenanceHistory, which usually will be a record of the creation of the instance. There may be many other maintenanceEvent elements documenting the milestone changes or activities in the maintenance of the instance.

A required child element of mandates used for identifying the source of authority or mandate for the corporate body in terms of its powers, functions, responsibilities or activities, such as a law, directive, or charter.
date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1), placeName (0..n), term (1..n)

mandate is used to identify the source of authority or mandate for the entity being described in terms of its powers, functions, responsibilities or sphere of activities, such as a law, directive, or charter.

mandate must include at least one term element. Terms may be drawn from controlled vocabularies or may be natural language terms. term can be repeated within mandate to include translations of the same mandate. Use the languageOfElement attribute to identify the language used in each term.

Associated date(s) (date, dateRange, or dateSet) and place(s) (placeName) may be included to further constrain the term's meaning. A descriptiveNote may be included if a fuller textual explanation is needed.
Multiple mandate elements may be grouped within a mandates element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: One of date, dateRange, or dateSet

div.p: An optional child element of description used for grouping together one or more mandate elements.
mandates groups together one or more occurrences of mandate. mandates must include at least one mandate element.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Number of microfilm readers available in the searchroom.
An element for encoding generic names.
An element containing a name entry for the repository being described.
Within identity, the element nameEntry is used to record a name by which the repository described in the EAG instance is known.
When nameEntry occurs within nameEntrySet it is used to record two or more forms of a name, for example official and non-official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts.
Each form of the name is recorded in a separate nameEntry element.
Each nameEntry must contain at least one part element. Within nameEntry each of the component parts of a name may be recorded in a separate part element.
The nameEntry element may also contain a useDates element to indicate the dates the name was used.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

list.item: The status attribute may be used to indicate whether the nameEntry is an authorized or alternative form of the name.

The scriptOfElement and languageOfElement attributes can be used to specify the script and language of each name recorded in several nameEntry elements, especially when used in parallel to each other.

div.p: Within identity: one of nameEntry or nameEntrySet required, repeatable
Within nameEntrySet: two or more nameEntry-s required, repeatable

A child element of identity used as a wrapper element for two or more nameEntry elements representing different forms of the same name (e.g., official and non-official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts).

A wrapper element used to group two or more nameEntry elements representing parallel or other forms of the name for the same repository which are used at the same time (e.g., official and non-official forms of the name in different languages and/or scripts).
The nameEntrySet element may contain a useDates element to indicate the dates the set of name forms was used.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:
Within identity: one of nameEntry or nameEntrySet required, repeatable
Concrete number or amount including the respective unit of measurement.
computerPlaces, extent, lengthOfShelves, microfilmPlaces, repositoryArea, workPlaces
Allows to provide a concrete number or amount including the respective unit of measurement in the accompanying attribute unit.
An optional child element of relation, setComponent, and source that allows for the inclusion of an XML element from any XML namespace other than EAC-CPF.
A wrapper element that provides a place to express data in any XML encoding language.
To facilitate interoperability the XML should conform to an open, standard XML schema and a namespace attribute should be present on the root element referencing the namespace of the standard.
It is also possible to encode data in XML without a namespace within the objectXML element.

objectXMLWrap may be used to store related XML data locally rather than linking to external resources in order to facilitate processing or in cases where the related data may not be reliably accessible.

eag:timetable.eag:opening: Consulta en sala: de lunes a viernes de 8.30 a 14.30 horas. Información y asuntos generales: de lunes a viernes de 8.30 a 14:30 horas

div.p: An optional child element of maintenanceAgency that provides an alternative code for the institution or service responsible for the EAC-CPF instance.

Use otherAgencyCode to provide an alternative and/or local code that represents the institution or service responsible for the creation, maintenance, and/or dissemination of the EAC-CPF instance. Any code other than that given in agencyCode may be provided in otherAgencyCode. The addition of an ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code as the prefix to a local code is recommended to ensure international uniqueness.

list.item: Use localType to specify the type of code being provided.
Use status to encode whether the otherAgencyCode is an authorized or alternative code.

div.p: An optional child element of control that encodes any local identifier for the EAC-CPF instance.

otherRecordId can be used to record an identifier that is an alternative to the mandatory identifier provided in recordId. These might include the identifiers of merged EAC-CPF instances representing the same CPF entity or those of records that are no longer current but had some part in the history and maintenance of the EAC-CPF instance.

list.item: Use localType to identify the institution or service responsible for providing the associated record identifier, if not the same as that given in maintenanceAgency.

div.p: Any other identifier used by the institution being described.
Any other identifier used by the institution being described, not necessarily compliant with ISO 15511 as recommended in repositoryId and its attribute repositoryCode.

list.item: Use the attributes vocabularySoure and/or vocabularySoureURI to indicate the code list or original system from where the alternative identifier is taken. Use the attribute valueURI to point to the specific identifier in an alternative code list.

div.p: A required child element of otherRepositoryTypes used to encode alternative repository types such as translations or specifications of respeectively additions to the predefined values used in repositoryType.
date or dateRange or dateSet (0..1), descriptiveNote (0..1), placeName (0..n), term (1..n)

The types of institutions with archival holdings might be defined by a regional or national archives association. If existing, enter terms in accordance with such conventions. Terms may be drawn from controlled vocabularies or may be natural language terms.

otherRepositoryType must include at least one term element, where the type of repository is encoded. term can be repeated within otherRepositoryType to include translations of the same term. Use the languageOfElement attribute to identify the language used in each term.

Associated date(s) (date, dateRange, or dateSet) and place(s) (placeName) may be included to further constrain the term's meaning. A descriptiveNote element may be included if a fuller textual explanation is needed.
Multiple otherRepositoryType elements may be grouped within an otherRepositoryTypes element.
The prescribed order of all child elements is:

div.p: An optional child element of identity used to bundle together one or more otherRepositoryType elements.

Use the element otherRepositoryTypes to provide more specific terms to the ones predefined for repositoryType or to provide translations of or equivalents to the predefined terms in your country's context.
otherRepositoryTypes requires at least one otherRepositoryType element to be present and includes the optional, not repeatable descriptiveNote element for further explanatory text if necessary.
The prescribed order of all child elements (both required and optional) is:

eag:descriptiveNote.eag:p: Translation of the term "National Archives" into Spanish

Any additional services provided at the repository; educational services, family activities, day of public archives, heritage day, etc.
